content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="H C O O H, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, is in equilibrium with, H 3 O with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus H C O O with a negative 1 charge, aqueous. K a, equals 1.8 times 10 to the negative 4 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtext>HCOOH</mtext><mtext></mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>HCOO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

Methanoic acid, <math alttext="H C O O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCOOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, ionizes according to the equation above.

(a) Write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K a" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, for the reaction.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="H C O O H, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, is in equilibrium with, H 3 O with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus H C O O with a negative 1 charge, aqueous. K a, equals 1.8 times 10 to the negative 4 power" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mtext>HCOOH</mtext><mtext></mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>HCOO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.8</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

Methanoic acid, <math alttext="H C O O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCOOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, ionizes according to the equation above.

(a) Write the expression for the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K a" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math>, for the reaction.

(b) Calculate the <math alttext="p H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>pH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a <math alttext="0.25 molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.25</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of <math alttext="H C O O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCOOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) In the box below, complete the Lewis electron-dot diagram for <math alttext="H C O O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCOOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show all bonding and nonbonding valence electrons.

<math alttext="H 2 N N H 2, aqueous, plus H 2 O, liquid, is in equilibrium with, H 2 N N H 3 with a positive 1 charge, aqueous, plus O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous. K b equals 1.3 times 10 to the negative 6 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NNH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NNH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext></mtd><mtd><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>
(d) In aqueous solution, the compound <math alttext="H 2 N N H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NNH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> reacts according to the equation above. A <math alttext="50.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="0.25 molar H 2 N N H 2, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.25</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>NNH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is combined with a <math alttext="50.0 milliliter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="0.25 molar H C O O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.25</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>HCOOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(i) Write the balanced net ionic equation for the reaction that occurs when <math alttext="H 2 N N H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>NNH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> is combined with <math alttext="H C O O H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCOOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(ii) Is the resulting solution acidic, basic, or neutral? Justify your answer.

When a catalyst is added to a solution of <math alttext="H C O O H, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>O</mtext><mtext>H</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, the reaction represented by the following equation occurs.
<math alttext="H C O O H, aqueous, reacts to produce H 2 gas, plus C O 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCOOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
(e) Is the reaction a redox reaction? Justify your answer.

(f) The reaction occurs in a rigid <math alttext="4.3 liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4.3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> vessel at <math alttext="25 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the total pressure is monitored, as shown in the graph above. The vessel originally did not contain any gas. Calculate the number of moles of <math alttext="C O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced in the reaction. (Assume that the amount of <math alttext="C O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> dissolved in the solution is negligible.)
(g) After the reaction has proceeded for several minutes, does the amount of catalyst increase, decrease, or remain the same? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
